While traditional models in chemical physics and mathematical biology continue to provide valuable insights and improve our understanding of complex systems, more realistic modeling of biological and chemical systems and efficient simulation methodologies have also been developed. In this minisymposium, a variety of computational models for chemical and biological applications will be discussed, ranging from agent-based and compartmental modeling to continuum modeling. In addition to analytical and theoretical results, recent progress in computational approaches will be presented, including the development of multi-scale hybrid simulation methodologies, high-performance computing packages, uncertainty quantification and machine learning techniques.

meeting.EventName: MS14 Advances in Variational Methods and Applications to Materials and Machine Learning - Part II of V
meeting.EventDescription: This minisymposium brings together new and established researchers in the Calculus of Variations to discuss both theory and application. From a variational perspective, researchers will introduce the audience to the state-of-the-art in theory, materials science, and the fast-developing field of machine learning. Looking at these disciplines in tandem will elucidate the broad overlap in approaches and inspire new connections for problems with fundamentally different applications. Some topics to be considered include adversarial training, curvature flows (from classical and large data perspectives), homogenization, elasticity, robust statistics, etc.

meeting.EventName: MS15 AWM Workshop: Graph Theory and Applications - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: This minisymposium is part of the Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM) Workshop and features a selection of speakers from AWM’s Research Network for Women in Graph Theory and Applications (WIGA). WIGA’s first Research Collaboration Conference for Women took place in August 2019 at the Institute for Mathematics and Its Applications (University of Minnesota-Minneapolis). In this conference, participants performed collaborative research in six teams, each focused on problems in a different area within graph theory and applications. All these teams continued their research collaboration after the conference and the goal of this minisymposium is to offer WIGA an opportunity to showcase their research accomplishments, and at the same time, to provide a forum for the discussion of current research questions leading to future research and to the incorporation of new mathematicians to WIGA. The research presented covers a broad variety of topics in graph theory and applications, including edge-density conditions for long cycles, graph searching, metric dimension, reconfiguration problems, creating chaos by breaking symmetries and coding theory. The scope of our minisymposium comprises graduate students and researchers, at different levels, focused on graph theory and its applications. Graduate students and researchers in other fields of mathematics who apply graph theory or have a strong interest in the area, might also be interested in this minisymposium.

meeting.EventName: MS16 Low Rank Methods for Big Data - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: The explosion of data brings unprecedented computational challenges as the cost of basic matrix operations can become prohibitively expensive for large-scale data. To reduce the computational complexity, low rank approximations are often used and have seen applications in molecular biology, fluid dynamics, statistics, machine learning, etc. Study on how to quickly obtain a compact low rank approximation that works for general kernel functions, how to implement the method in a high performance environment, how the method can be applied to different applications, is essential for the success of low rank methods. This minisymposium aims to bring together researchers in the field to discuss most recent development in low rank methods for resolving problems in big data.

meeting.EventName: MS17 Machine Learning in Finance: Theory and Applications - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Machine learning in finance sits at the intersection of a number of emergent and established disciplines including financial econometric, stochastic analysis, statistical computing, and machine learning. With the trend towards increasing computational resources and larger financial datasets, this topic has recently gained a lot of attention in the mathematical finance community.
This minisymposium aims to provide some state-of-the-art research topics related to (but not limited to) the mathematical and probabilistic understanding of deep learning and reinforcement learning, game theory, training algorithms, universal approximations theorems in dynamic settings, and their connections and applications to various problems in finance and concrete questions from the industry. We hope that this minisymposium could bring more researchers together and promote more discussions on the subject.

meeting.EventName: MS18 Mathematics of Transforming Structures and (Meta-)Materials - Part II of V
meeting.EventDescription: Origami (and kirigami) has inspired transforming structures across many length scales: from space applications such as the James Webb telescope to biomedical applications in the form of minimally invasive stents, DNA-based structures, and more. Concurrently, a wide array of materials have been developed which can transform, compute, and/or have novel, reconfigurable properties–often in response to external stimuli such as heat, applied electromagnetic fields, etc. Recognizing the complementary nature of these topics, this minisymposium aims to bring together researchers from each in order to highlight past, and inspire future, interdisciplinary work. More specifically, this minisymposium invites researchers exploring mathematical and theoretical mechanical approaches to emerging materials, metamaterials, and transforming structures that couple mechanics and deformation to other physics, especially for large deformations and shape changes. It also particularly aims to build connections to complementary experimental efforts.

meeting.EventName: MS19 Model Reduction and Stochastic Simulation of Multi-Scale Dynamic Problems - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Computational modeling of complex dynamic systems is a long-standing problem relevant to physics, chemistry, engineering, and system biology. Numerical methods based on model reduction and multi-scale simulation provide an essential tool to understand the influence of the inherent noise and the dynamic properties of these systems beyond equilibrium. The synergy of model reduction and numerical solutions techniques often leads to novel ideas and promotes the method development in dimension reduction, stochastic models, and solvers. In this mini-symposium, we focus on both model reduction and simulation methods with emphasis on the interaction of the state-of-art computational techniques on dimension reduction theory, uncertainty quantification, and machine-learning-based modeling. We invite speakers from both communities and expect them to have fruitful discussions with special emphasis on predictive modeling with interpretation, reliability, and numerically robustness and efficiency. The speakers will address model reduction and simulation techniques to solve multi-scale dynamic problems arising in various applications. Specific topics include stochastic modeling with applications to biology and chemical reaction systems, hydrodynamics of multiscale fluid systems, surrogate model methods, long-time integration of stochastic differential equations, probabilistic modeling, and dimension reduction.
